results.title: Emulation of Team Fortress for PC
results.creator_credit: Ian Caughley, John Cook, Robin Walker and Team Fortress Software
results.brief_description:
Team Fortress is a team and class-based multiplayer online first-person shooter video game mod based on id Software’s Quake Engine. The game has two teams battling it out in game modes like territorial control, capture the flag and escorting a VIP. A high degree of teamwork and cooperation is required to achieve these goals. This is embodied by the game’s class system. A player has a choice of nine different classes to play, each with its own strengths, weaknesses and skills that complement the other classes.

Due to its success, the developers were hired by Valve to mod it for their own game, Half-Life. This eventually led to a series of tweaks, enhancements and additions to the base game, eventually releasing as a standalone version titled Team Fortress Classic.

results.title: What is solarpunk?
results.brief_description: This viral TikTok video is one of the best crash courses on solarpunk out there. Clocking over 2M views, 453.9K likes, and 1,996 comments, it explains the hopeful, rebellious aesthetic blending futuristic tech with eco-friendly values. The “punk” fights capitalism and consumerism, while “solar” is both renewable energy and a metaphorical light in cyberpunk’s dystopian shadow. With clips from Studio Ghibli, the game Solarpunk, and Chobani’s Dear Alice ad, it nails the vibe, even if true solarpunk ideals go deeper. Part of a growing trend of low-cost, high-impact explainer videos, it shows how big ideas can thrive on small screens.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

results.title: Beneath Roads
results.creator_credit: Jenna Warwick, Rah Dakota and Field Carr
results.material_description:
mutli-channel, colour, black and white, sound
9 min 7 sec
results.brief_description:
Beneath Roads is a response to a purposeful void in Australia’s collective knowledge. Long before horses and carts found their way across the country, the land was crisscrossed by Indigenous pathways that remain the foundation for countless highways and roadways today.

Knowledge of these routes, their features and cultural significance is depicted in songs, which are memorised and passed down through generations. These traditional forms of navigation and spiritual understanding of place are known as Songlines. Many of the roads you drive on today are the result of this practice. One of the most identifiable pathways in Victoria navigated for centuries is the Omeo highway connecting north-east Victoria to Gippsland through Ngarigo, Jaitmatang and Gunnai Kurnai Country.

This visual poem ruminates on the layering of bitumen over these ancient routes through the lens of Australian cinema. The portrayal of the outback on screen has become one of this nation’s most recognisable cultural exports and the road genre offers one way to unpack a constructed national identity.

ABOUT THE SOURCES

Beneath Roads is assembled from a range of different film sources.

Ivan Sen’s debut feature, the road film Beneath Clouds (2002), considers the unresolved tensions of settler Australia. As two Indigenous teenagers, Vaughn (Damien Pitt) and Lena (Dannielle Hall), hitchhike toward Sydney, their journey is defined more by racism than the freedom that the road often symbolises. Director of photography Allan Collins captures the landscape as one hemmed in by powerlines and overcast skies, the terrain patrolled by cops and trampled by industry. But despite these settler interventions, the beauty and grandeur of Country prospers, captured through wide vistas and intimate close-ups of the landscape. Both Sen and Collins won an AACTA award for Best Director and Best Cinematography respectively.

Beneath Clouds and other narrative titles are juxtaposed with archival historical films about Australian road building. These Government-made promotional films of the 1950s and 60s were used to build support for ‘nation building’ and were released during the same period First Peoples gained the right to vote in 1962. These are included in Beneath Roads to highlight the lack of awareness of centuries-old Indigenous navigation and travel routes upon which many modern roads were built.

Beneath Roads further counters this lack of awareness by including footage of the Southern Warriors, a Victorian Aboriginal motorcycle club. On Survival Day in 2024, the Southern Warriors rode to Coranderrk mission to honour Wurundjeri activist William Barak’s historic protest walks from Coranderrk to Melbourne, during which Barak advocated for the mission and his people’s rights. Historically First Peoples’ ability to travel was restricted by systemic racism and discriminatory government policies that pervaded Australia until the 1970s. The Southern Warriors stand in stark contrast to this history, representing a sense of freedom, safety and pride for Indigenous communities. Impossible to ignore, the self-described ‘warriors’ travel the state Black, loud and proud.

results.title: After the End
results.brief_description:
Australia’s landscapes are home to massive infrastructures of extraction. The country’s economy is so defined by mining and fossil fuel projects that ending our reliance on them would mean reimagining how we live and who we are.

After the End creates a new story for Australia. Beginning 50,000 years ago, it explores the journey of the earliest First Nations communities, through colonisation and its history of resource extraction, to a hopeful tomorrow where fossil fuels are banned and stolen lands returned.
But what happens to the enormous industrial structures left to sit like scars on the earth? Do we melt them down and reshape them into new cities, preserve them as symbols of our past, or let them decay and return to the earth?

In this future, island communities form above oil rigs turned into artificial reefs, while an Indigenous space industry launches from old gas plants. After the End follows the First Peoples who return to the land, reclaim their sovereignty, and weave these machines into their new lives on Country.

Planetary Punk
“The giant machines have been reborn. Now they stand as launchpads for the future, not beasts of destruction but beings of light and memory.” – Natasha Wanganeen

After the End was filmed and takes place on Ngarrindjeri, Narungga, Kaurna and Noongar woman Natasha Wanganeen’s Country in South Australia. This includes the Yorke Peninsula, and surrounding areas, encompassing the Olympic Dam mine, the Cooper Basin, and the Maralinga / Woomera nuclear test sites. The Olympic Dam mine is the largest single deposit of uranium in the world, and the fourth largest copper deposit; the Cooper Basin has Australia’s most important oil and gas deposits; and the UK conducted seven nuclear tests at Maralinga / Woomera from 1956 to 1963. This colonial and environmental destruction is referenced in After the End, with Wanganeen’s poetic narrative and Young’s visuals envisioning First Peoples reclaiming Country and the infrastructure of extraction.

While cyberpunk explores virtual subcultures and solarpunk imagines positive environmental communities, After the End represents a new style – ‘Planetary Punk’, which adapts global infrastructure to create post-colonial climate solutions.

constellations_primary.description: Sue Ford's Egami reimagines contemporary life through a feminist and colonial lens.

results.description:
As the world comes together to end fossil fuels these massive remnants of industry sit like scars on the earth. Constant reminders of who we once were. What do we do with these dinosaurs? Are they melted down and recast as new cities, are they reoccupied and squatted on, or left to decay and return to the ground from which they came? This story follows the communities that return to the land from which they were once removed and take back these machines, to weave them into their new lives on Country.

South Australia is home to some of the largest excavations on earth: holes in the ground so large that they generate their own weather systems, chasms cut out of sacred ground, reformed earth that has shipped precious Country across the world boat by boat. What will become of these scars and how can the communities that belong to this land reassert their sovereignty?

Out on the vast seas, giant cities have been sucking oil from beneath the ocean floor and poisoning the waters. When the tap is turned off, do we let them rust into the sea, drag them back to shore or create new island nations?

Gas plumes light up the skies over stolen land. Tangled webs of pipelines, valves and reservoirs that could be dismantled, repurposed or burnt to the ground. The sky has been colonised just as the land has. In the 1950s, the South Australian ground shook with the nuclear tests of the British Empire, today the coastline is home to a multi-billion-dollar space industry launching satellites of the techno-industrial complex into the stars.

Beginning 50,000 years ago, After the End tells the story of Australia, from the earliest first nations communities, through colonisation and the history of extraction to a near future when fossil fuels are banned and stolen lands are returned. From the shadows of industry communities return to reassert their sovereignty and reimagine the massive scars left behind. New island communities are formed above the remains of oil rigs sunken as artificial reefs and a sovereign satellite network is launched for a new Indigenous space industry built on the concrete pads of aging gas plants.

results.title: Birth of Dawn
results.brief_description:
Hannah Brontë’s Birth of Dawn explores the cycle of life, birth, death and rebirth through the lens of the femme body. The sun, reimagined as a pregnant belly, symbolises the moment before new life enters the world. The work invites us to consider the Earth as a living, breathing body and questions how we move across it.

Set on a planet yet to experience its first dawn, this dreamscape merges ancient and futuristic landscapes, free from man-made objects. The inhabitants communicate through movement and telepathic frequencies projected through the soundscape. Having evolved beyond language, they experience every emotion that comes with growth – pain and pleasure ripple across each frame.

Birth of Dawn transports you into the present moment through bass-heavy waves, where past and future merge into one continuous cycle. There is no beginning or end here – only the infinite potential of new life and transformation.

There is nothing more science fiction than nature itself.

Created on the unceded lands of Yugambeh, Arakwal and Bundjalung Country

constellations_primary.name: Scripture for spiritual connections and sci-fi futures
constellations_primary.description: Connections between people, animals and the environment in sci-fi stories, videogames, art and film.

results.description:
The sun rises and sets, followed by the moon’s rotation each day — there is always a new beginning. The sun is reimagined as a pregnant belly, the moment before new life enters this rotation. If we treat the earth as another breathing body, how do we move across it? The present is pregnant with the future. You are transported to a planet that has yet to experience its first Birth of Dawn.

Birth and death rituals are explored through the framework of the femme body. The cycle of being born, flourishing, rotting, decaying, and beginning again repeats within dreamscapes untouched by man-made objects. There is no beginning nor end to this portal. These landscapes are both ancient and futuristic, their immense knowledge and technology seamlessly woven into every ecosystem. There is nothing more science fiction than nature itself.

The inhabitants experience every emotion that accompanies growth—pain and pleasure ripple across each frame. They communicate through movement and telepathic frequencies, having evolved beyond language. As they prepare for birth, their internal thoughts are projected through the soundscape, carrying us from moonlight to daybreak, over and over. Swimming through bass-heavy tides, this work seeks to transport you not forward or backward, but to expand you into the present moment, where past, present, and future are intertwined as one.

“We rot and become god again. Impregnated with possibility, I birth new dawns. Open. Fecund. Cycles. Spiral up, up, up with me. I see you. I see you in the ocean; I see you in the lava. Stay open. Stay tender every chance you get. Split your heart wide open and let it expand with me. Let’s run!”

  • Hannah Brontë

Created on the unceded lands of Yugambeh, Arakwal and Bundjalung Country

Costume materials: Salvaged fishing net, fish scales, abalone, clam, pippi, cowrie, mother of pearl, stingray bone, wire, muslin, silk, stocking, natural dyes, wool, silicone, pearls, glass, wire, palm bark, cotton twine.

Costume contribution by Megan Hanson from previous work

Videographer: Aidan Rice

Sound: Jesse Koroi

Vocals: Mayan Hennemeyer

Editor: Kate O’Sullivan

Models: Kel Knox, Clea Prat, Lisa Kelly , Mayatu Nova, Sasskia Sassen , Drea Lam, Taree Sansbury, Naomi Appo, Eilla Appo, Hannah Brontë
